<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/03/covid19-traffic-report?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Introducing the COVID-19 Traffic Report
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Empty highway " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NzIvaGlnaHdheS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Nearly empty North Luzon Expressway in metro Manila, Philippines. Ezra Acayan/Getty Images.</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With so much coronavirus business news, it’s hard to separate what’s important from what’s happening on Jack Black’s TikTok. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Thank goodness for <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=emtech&email={email}" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Emerging Tech Brew</a> writer Ryan Duffy. He’s distilled all the biggest digital and IRL traffic trends into a <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/04/03/covid-traffic-report?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">single report</a>, and we’ve distilled all the biggest takeaways here. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Online traffic has surged</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the social distancing era, school is virtual, work is virtual, and power hours are virtual. Our network infrastructure is carrying a freshman backpack of internet traffic, but it appears to be holding up.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Comcast, which operates the largest residential internet network in the U.S., reported </span><span><a href="https://corporate.comcast.com/covid-19/network?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">peak traffic</a></span><span> that’s up 32% overall since March 1.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Virgin Media said upstream traffic in the daytime has jumped 95% mainly due to work-from-homers uploading files to their corporate networks.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If that sounds way more productive than your own quarantine experience, these stats will make you feel better:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Nokia reported 400% growth in gaming traffic during U.S. business hours from March 16–March 22. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The week of March 22 saw </span><span><a href="https://www.appannie.com/en/insights/mobile-gaming/social-distancing-accelerates-multiplayer-mobile-gaming/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">1.2 billion downloads</a></span><span> of mobile games—the biggest week ever for downloads, per App Annie. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Mobile apps separate into winners and losers</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Winners:<strong style="color:#000"></strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Some grocery delivery apps, </strong></span><span>including Instacart, Walmart Grocery, and Shipt, hit </span><span><a href="https://blog.apptopia.com/instacart-and-grocery-delivery-apps-set-consecutive-days-of-record-downloads?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">record downloads</a></span><span> in mid-March, per Apptopia.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Business conference apps </strong></span><span>had their biggest download week ever March 14–21.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Health and fitness apps </strong></span><span>saw a surge in downloads. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Losers: <strong style="color:#000"></strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Travel app downloads </strong></span><span>dipped 31% in March.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Music app downloads </strong></span><span>were also slightly down. Same with podcasts.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Ride-sharing app downloads </strong></span><span>have collapsed.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Most people have become couch potatoes</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you aren’t an essential worker, the chances you’ve changed zip codes in the past few weeks are slim. One fun piece of supporting evidence is the speed of freight traffic through busy intersections.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>On I-495 in Queens, NY, trucks reached rush hour speeds of 38 mph in mid-March, compared to the 16 mph average, </span><span><a href="https://truckingresearch.org/2020/03/24/gps-data-shows-critical-truck-deliveries-continue-despite-covid-19-analysis-of-data-finds-unprecedented-performance-year-over-year/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reports the ATRI</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Freight traffic normally moves through Atlanta’s Spaghetti Junction at below 15 mph during rush hour. The week of March 23, truck speeds averaged 53 mph.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Want more? You can flip through the <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/04/03/covid-traffic-report?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">full report here</a>.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/03/streak-job-gains-us?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Streak Is Over
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="March jobs report data" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NjkvbWFyY2hfam9ic19yZXBvcnRfZGF0YS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/business/economy/coronavirus-jobs-report.html" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">New York Times</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After 113 consecutive months of job gains, the U.S. economy posted <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/business/economy/coronavirus-jobs-report.html?action=click&module=Spotlight&pgtype=Homepage&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">negative nonfarm payrolls</a> in March.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Payrolls fell by 701,000 last month, </strong>the biggest monthly decline since March 2009. The unemployment rate also jumped to 4.4% from 3.5% in February, the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-jobs-report-likely-to-show-start-of-record-labor-market-collapse-11585906617?mod=hp_lead_pos5&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">biggest month-on-month increase</a> since January 1975. That’s the bad news. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The worse news:</strong> The Labor Department mainly collected the data in the first half of the month. Early March might feel like a lifetime ago, but if you can remember, it was before state governments began enforcing shutdowns to stop the spread of the coronavirus. Those shutdowns forced millions of layoffs...meaning April’s report is going to be way, way worse. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How bad? </strong>St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said unemployment <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-03/u-s-payrolls-fall-701-000-in-march-ahead-of-surge-in-layoffs?srnd=premium&sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">could hit 30%</a> this quarter. Oxford Economics thinks the jobless rate will hit 16% and the economy will lose 27.9 million jobs by May. That would more than double the jobs lost in the last recession.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SMALL BIZ
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/03/small-business-loan-program-goes-live?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Ready...Set...Borrow
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">U.S. small businesses rocked by social distancing measures got their first crack at $349 billion in emergency loans from the government yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It was a pretty chaotic day, as expected. Bank of America was <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/03/bank-of-americas-small-business-loan-portal-is-up-making-it-the-first-bank-to-accept-applications.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ready to go</a> in the morning, but JPMorgan didn’t begin accepting applications until after 1pm. Wells Fargo said it wouldn’t be able to receive any applications yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>The small business loan program, known as the <a href="https://www.vox.com/coronavirus-covid19/2020/4/2/21204341/paycheck-protection-program-apply-small-business-loans-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Paycheck Protection Program</a> (PPP), is the centerpiece of the $2.2 trillion economic relief bill passed just over a week ago. That short window meant the full details of PPP weren’t made public until Thursday night. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“Having just received guidance outlining how to implement a $349 billion program literally hours before it starts, we would ask for everyone to be patient,” said Richard Hunt, head of the Consumer Bankers Association. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Patience will be excruciating for the small businesses across America with just a few weeks of cash on hand. And <a href="https://www.axios.com/skepticism-rises-over-governments-small-business-bailouts-dfb57d82-32f8-433f-8eda-f9f267836fbc.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">no one knows</a> yet whether demand for these loans will outstrip the available funds.</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY ACQUIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

<font color="#000000">
Digital Experiences Speak Louder Than Words
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.acquia.com/?cid=7013a000002L6xUAAS&ct=display&ls=morningbrew&lls=pro_na_morningbrew_ola_q12020" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Acquia" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL3BsYWNlbWVudC9pbWFnZXMvNDk2LzE1ODUwNjkwMTQtQ3JlYXRpdmVfTW9ybmluZ19CcmV3X0FkX3YxXzEtMDIucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0IjoiY29tZXQtbW9ybmluZ2JyZXciLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We could shout, “<a href="https://www.acquia.com/?cid=7013a000002L6xUAAS&ct=display&ls=morningbrew&lls=pro_na_morningbrew_ola_q12020" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Acquia</a> has all the tools and expertise you need to <strong style="color:#000">craft digital experiences</strong> that inspire action and deliver results!”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We could scream, “<a href="https://www.acquia.com/?cid=7013a000002L6xUAAS&ct=display&ls=morningbrew&lls=pro_na_morningbrew_ola_q12020" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Acquia</a> is the most trusted expert for <strong style="color:#000">open experience digital platforms</strong>! They power websites, applications, and online experiences for<strong style="color:#000"> the world’s biggest brands</strong>!”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And all that would be <a href="https://www.acquia.com/resources/case-study?cid=7013a000002L6xUAAS&ct=display&ls=morningbrew&lls=pro_na_morningbrew_ola_q12020" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">true</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The thing is, we can’t possibly hope to capture the <a href="https://www.acquia.com/resources/case-study?cid=7013a000002L6xUAAS&ct=display&ls=morningbrew&lls=pro_na_morningbrew_ola_q12020" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">power</a> of Acquia’s digital experiences with words in a newsletter. We can’t hope to truly communicate what your customers will <a href="https://www.acquia.com/resources/case-study?cid=7013a000002L6xUAAS&ct=display&ls=morningbrew&lls=pro_na_morningbrew_ola_q12020" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">feel</a> when they consistently experience personalized, finely-crafted digital content.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So instead of reading our words about how great Acquia is—about how Acquia’s digital experiences let you <strong style="color:#000">understand, personalize, and engage with customers</strong> through any channel—<a href="https://www.acquia.com/?cid=7013a000002L6xUAAS&ct=display&ls=morningbrew&lls=pro_na_morningbrew_ola_q12020" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">just click here and experience Acquia for yourself</a>.</p>
</td>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MANUFACTURING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/03/3m-defends-n95-mask-production-trump-lashes?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
No Coincidence 3M Rhymes With GM
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Sparring with President Trump over commitments to produce critical medical supplies is officially a spring Friday tradition for American manufacturers. Last week, the President <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/27/president-trump-gm-continue-beef-ventilator-production?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suggested</a> GM was moving too slowly in cranking out ventilators and invoked “the P” (aka the Defense Production Act).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Yesterday, it was 3M’s turn.</strong> The manufacturer went on the defense over its production of invaluable N95 masks after taking heat from the White House.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Some background: </strong>On Thursday, President Trump <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/04/03/826629472/slammed-by-trump-3m-says-n95-mask-exports-from-u-s-should-continue?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">attacked 3M on Twitter</a>, insinuating it’ll “have a big price to pay” for its handling of N95 mask production. He again invoked the Defense Production Act, this time forcing 3M to make as many masks as FEMA wants. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The U.S. has the capacity to make about 50 million N95 masks monthly. 3M </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/3m-under-attack-from-white-house-pushes-back-11585922687?mod=hp_lead_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">makes some 35 million</a></span><span> of them.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What 3M is doing:</strong> hitting back, saying yesterday that the White House’s allegations are “<a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-03/trump-s-battle-with-3m-on-masks-escalates-over-u-s-exports?srnd=premium&sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">absurd</a>” and that it’s raised domestic production and started importing masks from its China plant.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What 3M isn’t doing:</strong> complying with Trump’s request to stop exporting U.S.-made masks to Canada and Latin America, citing “significant” humanitarian concerns and fear that retaliation might actually leave the U.S. with fewer masks.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SATURDAY HEADLINES
</h3>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you told us a month ago there wouldn't be a single restaurant open for sit-in dining in all of New York City we wouldn't have believed you. Here are some other unbelievable headlines from the week's news, plus a fake one we dropped in. Can you spot the odd one out? </p>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“Shaq criticized for </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-28/shaq-criticized-for-skipping-too-many-papa-john-s-board-meetings?cmpid=BBD033120_OUS&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_term=200331&utm_campaign=openamericas&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">skipping</a></span><span> too many Papa John’s board meetings”</span>

Ezra Acayan/Getty Images.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith so much coronavirus business news, it’s hard to separate what’s important from what’s happening on Jack Black’s TikTok. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThank goodness for \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=emtech\u0026email={email}\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eEmerging Tech Brew\u003c/a\u003e writer Ryan Duffy. He’s distilled all the biggest digital and IRL traffic trends into a \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/04/03/covid-traffic-report?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esingle report\u003c/a\u003e, and we’ve distilled all the biggest takeaways here. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eOnline traffic has surged\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the social distancing era, school is virtual, work is virtual, and power hours are virtual. Our network infrastructure is carrying a freshman backpack of internet traffic, but it appears to be holding up.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eComcast, which operates the largest residential internet network in the U.S., reported \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://corporate.comcast.com/covid-19/network?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epeak traffic\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e that’s up 32% overall since March 1.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eVirgin Media said upstream traffic in the daytime has jumped 95% mainly due to work-from-homers uploading files to their corporate networks.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf that sounds way more productive than your own quarantine experience, these stats will make you feel better:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNokia reported 400% growth in gaming traffic during U.S. business hours from March 16–March 22. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe week of March 22 saw \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.appannie.com/en/insights/mobile-gaming/social-distancing-accelerates-multiplayer-mobile-gaming/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e1.2 billion downloads\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of mobile games—the biggest week ever for downloads, per App Annie. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eMobile apps separate into winners and losers\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWinners:\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSome grocery delivery apps, \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eincluding Instacart, Walmart Grocery, and Shipt, hit \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://blog.apptopia.com/instacart-and-grocery-delivery-apps-set-consecutive-days-of-record-downloads?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erecord downloads\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in mid-March, per Apptopia.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBusiness conference apps \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ehad their biggest download week ever March 14–21.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHealth and fitness apps \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003esaw a surge in downloads. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLosers: \u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTravel app downloads \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003edipped 31% in March.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMusic app downloads \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ewere also slightly down. Same with podcasts.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRide-sharing app downloads \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ehave collapsed.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eMost people have become couch potatoes\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you aren’t an essential worker, the chances you’ve changed zip codes in the past few weeks are slim. One fun piece of supporting evidence is the speed of freight traffic through busy intersections.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOn I-495 in Queens, NY, trucks reached rush hour speeds of 38 mph in mid-March, compared to the 16 mph average, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://truckingresearch.org/2020/03/24/gps-data-shows-critical-truck-deliveries-continue-despite-covid-19-analysis-of-data-finds-unprecedented-performance-year-over-year/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereports the ATRI\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFreight traffic normally moves through Atlanta’s Spaghetti Junction at below 15 mph during rush hour. The week of March 23, truck speeds averaged 53 mph.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWant more? width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NjkvbWFyY2hfam9ic19yZXBvcnRfZGF0YS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/business/economy/coronavirus-jobs-report.html\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNew York Times\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter 113 consecutive months of job gains, the U.S. economy posted \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/03/business/economy/coronavirus-jobs-report.html?action=click\u0026module=Spotlight\u0026pgtype=Homepage\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enegative nonfarm payrolls\u003c/a\u003e in March.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePayrolls fell by 701,000 last month, \u003c/strong\u003ethe biggest monthly decline since March 2009. The unemployment rate also jumped to 4.4% from 3.5% in February, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-jobs-report-likely-to-show-start-of-record-labor-market-collapse-11585906617?mod=hp_lead_pos5\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebiggest month-on-month increase\u003c/a\u003e since January 1975. That’s the bad news. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe worse news:\u003c/strong\u003e The Labor Department mainly collected the data in the first half of the month. Early March might feel like a lifetime ago, but if you can remember, it was before state governments began enforcing shutdowns to stop the spread of the coronavirus. Those shutdowns forced millions of layoffs...meaning April’s report is going to be way, way worse. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow bad? \u003c/strong\u003eSt. Louis Fed President James Bullard said unemployment \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-03/u-s-payrolls-fall-701-000-in-march-ahead-of-surge-in-layoffs?srnd=premium\u0026sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecould hit 30%\u003c/a\u003e this quarter. Oxford Economics thinks the jobless rate will hit 16% and the economy will lose 27.9 million jobs by May. That would more than double the jobs lost in the last recession.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nReady...Set...Borrow\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eU.S. small businesses rocked by social distancing measures got their first crack at $349 billion in emergency loans from the government yesterday.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt was a pretty chaotic day, as expected. Bank of America was \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/03/bank-of-americas-small-business-loan-portal-is-up-making-it-the-first-bank-to-accept-applications.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eready to go\u003c/a\u003e in the morning, but JPMorgan didn’t begin accepting applications until after 1pm. Wells Fargo said it wouldn’t be able to receive any applications yesterday.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eThe small business loan program, known as the \u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/coronavirus-covid19/2020/4/2/21204341/paycheck-protection-program-apply-small-business-loans-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ePaycheck Protection Program\u003c/a\u003e (PPP), is the centerpiece of the $2.2 trillion economic relief bill passed just over a week ago. That short window meant the full details of PPP weren’t made public until Thursday night. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“Having just received guidance outlining how to implement a $349 billion program literally hours before it starts, we would ask for everyone to be patient,” said Richard Hunt, head of the Consumer Bankers Association. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePatience will be excruciating for the small businesses across America with just a few weeks of cash on hand. And \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/skepticism-rises-over-governments-small-business-bailouts-dfb57d82-32f8-433f-8eda-f9f267836fbc.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eno one knows\u003c/a\u003e yet whether demand for these loans will outstrip the available funds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nNo Coincidence 3M Rhymes With GM\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSparring with President Trump over commitments to produce critical medical supplies is officially a spring Friday tradition for American manufacturers. Last week, the President \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/27/president-trump-gm-continue-beef-ventilator-production?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuggested\u003c/a\u003e GM was moving too slowly in cranking out ventilators and invoked “the P” (aka the Defense Production Act).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eYesterday, it was 3M’s turn.\u003c/strong\u003e The manufacturer went on the defense over its production of invaluable N95 masks after taking heat from the White House.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSome background: \u003c/strong\u003eOn Thursday, President Trump \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/04/03/826629472/slammed-by-trump-3m-says-n95-mask-exports-from-u-s-should-continue?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eattacked 3M on Twitter\u003c/a\u003e, insinuating it’ll “have a big price to pay” for its handling of N95 mask production. He again invoked the Defense Production Act, this time forcing 3M to make as many masks as FEMA wants. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe U.S. has the capacity to make about 50 million N95 masks monthly. 3M \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/3m-under-attack-from-white-house-pushes-back-11585922687?mod=hp_lead_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emakes some 35 million\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of them.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat 3M is doing:\u003c/strong\u003e hitting back, saying yesterday that the White House’s allegations are “\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-03/trump-s-battle-with-3m-on-masks-escalates-over-u-s-exports?srnd=premium\u0026sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eabsurd\u003c/a\u003e” and that it’s raised domestic production and started importing masks from its China plant.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat 3M isn’t doing:\u003c/strong\u003e complying with Trump’s request to stop exporting U.S.-made masks to Canada and Latin America, citing “significant” humanitarian concerns and fear that retaliation might actually leave the U.S. with
